programme.title: Spiritual Explorers

programme.desc: The Hanamatsuri mountain village, dating back 700 years, features an evening of all-night dancing, bringing together deities and humans in a celebration of life.

programme.title: A Culture Built with Wood
programme.sub-title: Hida
programme.desc: The Hida region in Gifu Prefecture has some of the country's most extensive broadleaf forests. Here, local artisans with sophisticated woodworking techniques are referred to as "Hida's Master Craftsmen," a title that has been respected for 1,300 years. Their skills are showcased in the floats of the Takayama Autumn Festival, ranked among the 3 most beautiful festivals in Japan. These floats are crafted using Japanese wood joinery techniques and do not use a single nail. Join us as we examine the craftsmanship that interlocks with the Hida region.

programme.title: Satoyama Kitchen Diary
programme.sub-title: Veggies Patiently Pickled for the Cold Season
programme.desc: Hi! It's me, Tama. In winter, I never stray far away from my warm friend, Mr. Stove. But Grandpa Makoto and Grandma Nobuko are off to see our neighbor to learn how to make pickles. Not me. I'm staying right here. The only thing I need to know about pickles is how to eat them!

programme.title: Japanology Plus

programme.desc: *First broadcast on February 12, 2026 Salmon is Japan's most popular fish eaten at home. However, catches have been plummeting due to global warming. We look at new approaches to salmon farming and what this fish means to people in Japan.

programme.title: Document 72 Hours
programme.sub-title: The Convenience Store in a Midwinter Hokkaido Village
programme.desc: The Hokkaido village of Shosanbetsu is home to about 1,000 people and a single convenience store. Residents rely on this store as a source of fresh food and basic necessities, especially in midwinter. Among the customers were a woman who uses a sled to carry her shopping home; an octopus fisherman who shops there three times a day; and a hair stylist who knows everybody in Shosanbetsu. For three days as a blizzard buffeted the area, we spoke to the store's customers to get a glimpse at life in this village.

programme.title: Journeys in Japan
programme.sub-title: Noto: Lighting a Torch for the Future
programme.desc: Two years ago, on New Year's Day of 2024, a massive earthquake hit the Noto Peninsula in Ishikawa Prefecture, leaving over 200 dead and wrecking thousands of homes and other buildings. On this edition of Journeys in Japan, Kyle Card visits two of the worst-hit areas, to meet the people of Noto and see how they are starting to bounce back from tragedy and devastation. In Wajima, he meets people from the city's iconic Morning Market, who are working vigorously at a temporary location. And he meets with artisans who are keeping alive the traditions of Wajima-nuri lacquerware. He also visits a Buddhist temple, Soji-ji Soin, which suffered significant damage, and sees how the priests are restoring this essential pillar of the community. He then travels to Suzu City on the far tip of the peninsula, where he is astonished by the changes he finds to the natural landscape. He is also struck by the warmth of the staff at the Suzu Horse Park, who are working to provide healing for the local people through their interactions with the horses.

programme.title: IMPACTS: Climates Change the World
programme.sub-title: On the Brink of Extinction?: Episode 2 Melting Ice Accelerates the Polar Bear Crisis
programme.desc: The latest research highlights the polar region crisis, with the lowest ever levels of sea ice and a polar bear population 50% reduced in 42 years in some areas. We look at wildlife in the Arctic.

programme.title: Ukiyoe EDO-LIFE: Calligraphy Day
programme.sub-title: A Children's Calligraphy Gathering
programme.desc: We visit a terakoya, a school teaching reading and writing. Today the young students have come dressed in their finest, and are busy putting brush to paper to show off their calligraphy skills.

programme.title: Today's Close-Up
programme.sub-title: Hospice-Style Housing: New Option Emerges for End-Of-Life Care
programme.desc: Hospice-style housing is emerging as a new end-of-life housing option for people with terminal or incurable illnesses in Japan. These residences offer a level of comfort and care unavailable at nursing homes, and they are spreading rapidly at a time when hospital capacity is declining across the country. But they also present serious challenges. The quality of care varies dramatically by residence, and some operators have been known to overcharge for medical care. We talk to experts about the merits of hospice-style housing and what needs to be done to improve the system. Guests: Inoue Yukiko (Professor, Japan College of Social Work) Yamazaki Fumio (Honorary Director, Caretown Kodaira Clinic)

programme.title: Science View
programme.sub-title: Biomimicry Changes the Future of Robotics
programme.desc: Robotic engineering continues to evolve swiftly, yet developing a robot that can detect and pursue odors has proved difficult for the science. Shunsuke SHIGAKI, an assistant professor at Osaka University, seeks to address the problem by analyzing the scent-detection abilities of silk moths. To understand how airflow or sight affect their perception of scents, he built a VR unit for insects in order to gather data. The algorithm created from it allowed him to program a robot with similar odor-detection capabilities. Now, he attempts to give it enough environmental adaptability to navigate obstacles, or operate outdoors. In this episode, we follow SHIGAKI's efforts to create a high-tech robot with abilities learned from actual organisms, so that it might eventually be put to use in search and rescue operations.

programme.title: MATSURI: The Heartbeat of Japan
programme.sub-title: Hirosaki Neputa Matsuri: Hirosaki
programme.desc: Enormous floats called neputa paraded through the streets are the highlight of Hirosaki Neputa Matsuri in Hirosaki, Aomori Prefecture. The floats are decorated with vibrant images painted on washi paper. Some floats feature wireframe 3D figures. For most of the floats new art is produced every year, and preparations begin months in advance. This 300-year-old tradition began as a way to ward off drowsiness and keep people focused on farm work in the heat of summer.

programme.title: The World Heritage Sites in Japan
programme.sub-title: Intertwined Lives on Sea and Shore: Shiretoko, Hokkaido
programme.desc: The Shiretoko Peninsula, located in eastern Hokkaido Prefecture, juts into the Sea of Okhotsk. Its center is lined by 1,500-meter peaks. The heavily forested area is home to a diverse group of animals, including the Blakiston's fish owl, which is at imminent risk of extinction. Shiretoko's waters are home to creatures who feed off the bounty of floating pack ice. Explore an extraordinary ecosystem which connects the rich environments of both land and sea.

programme.title: YONEZAWA: A Gift from Melted Snow
programme.sub-title: YONEZAWA: A Gift from Melted Snow
programme.desc: As snow melts in Yonezawa, it provides water used for growing rice. Beautiful time-lapse images show how a 400-year-old brewery turns this rice into sake, using human expertise instead of machines.

programme.title: Time-lapse Journey
programme.sub-title: Iwate
programme.desc: Iwate Prefecture is home to many historic sites which were made to represent Buddhist paradise. Chuson-ji Temple in Hiraizumi, a World Heritage Site, is home to the golden Konjikido hall which offers a prayer for peace. The garden in Motsu-ji Temple was made as a depiction of paradise and has been also registered as a World Heritage Site. Catch a glimpse of eternity through time-lapse photography.

programme.title: FRONTRUNNERS

programme.title: Science View
programme.sub-title: Biomimicry Changes the Future of Robotics
programme.desc: Robotic engineering continues to evolve swiftly, yet developing a robot that can detect and pursue odors has proved difficult for the science. Shunsuke SHIGAKI, an assistant professor at Osaka University, seeks to address the problem by analyzing the scent-detection abilities of silk moths. To understand how airflow or sight affect their perception of scents, he built a VR unit for insects in order to gather data. The algorithm created from it allowed him to program a robot with similar odor-detection capabilities. Now, he attempts to give it enough environmental adaptability to navigate obstacles, or operate outdoors. In this episode, we follow SHIGAKI's efforts to create a high-tech robot with abilities learned from actual organisms, so that it might eventually be put to use in search and rescue operations.

programme.title: The World Heritage Sites in Japan
programme.sub-title: Intertwined Lives on Sea and Shore: Shiretoko, Hokkaido
programme.desc: The Shiretoko Peninsula, located in eastern Hokkaido Prefecture, juts into the Sea of Okhotsk. Its center is lined by 1,500-meter peaks. The heavily forested area is home to a diverse group of animals, including the Blakiston's fish owl, which is at imminent risk of extinction. Shiretoko's waters are home to creatures who feed off the bounty of floating pack ice. Explore an extraordinary ecosystem which connects the rich environments of both land and sea.

programme.title: MATSURI: The Heartbeat of Japan
programme.sub-title: Hirosaki Neputa Matsuri: Hirosaki
programme.desc: Enormous floats called neputa paraded through the streets are the highlight of Hirosaki Neputa Matsuri in Hirosaki, Aomori Prefecture. The floats are decorated with vibrant images painted on washi paper. Some floats feature wireframe 3D figures. For most of the floats new art is produced every year, and preparations begin months in advance. This 300-year-old tradition began as a way to ward off drowsiness and keep people focused on farm work in the heat of summer.

programme.sub-title: Minowa, Kanasugi, Mikawashima

programme.title: Today's Close-Up
programme.sub-title: Closer Than Friends or Family? — Turning to AI for Companionship
programme.desc: The struggles of everyday life are driving more and more people to use AI chatbots to fill the void in their hearts. Attracted by the sense of support and the constant availability, some have even 'married' AI characters, or recreated deceased partners to fill the feelings of loss. Meanwhile in the US, there have been cases where bereaved families have sued AI companies, claiming that the bots caused loved ones to take their own lives. We look into the way people use AI, along with some precautions it might be wise to take. Guest: Satoh Ichiro (Professor, National Institute of Informatics)

programme.title: Seasoning the Seasons
programme.sub-title: The Steep Paths of Naha: Nostalgia and Community
programme.desc: Naha, in Okinawa, is a hilly city. At the top of one prominent hill is Shuri Castle, which hosted the royal court of the Ryukyu Islands for 450 years. Naha, the center of Ryukyu culture, grew around the royal court. The steep paths linking the castle on the hill to the city below have always been part of community life.

programme.title: Journeys in Japan
programme.sub-title: Noto: Lighting a Torch for the Future
programme.desc: Two years ago, on New Year's Day of 2024, a massive earthquake hit the Noto Peninsula in Ishikawa Prefecture, leaving over 200 dead and wrecking thousands of homes and other buildings. On this edition of Journeys in Japan, Kyle Card visits two of the worst-hit areas, to meet the people of Noto and see how they are starting to bounce back from tragedy and devastation. In Wajima, he meets people from the city's iconic Morning Market, who are working vigorously at a temporary location. And he meets with artisans who are keeping alive the traditions of Wajima-nuri lacquerware. He also visits a Buddhist temple, Soji-ji Soin, which suffered significant damage, and sees how the priests are restoring this essential pillar of the community. He then travels to Suzu City on the far tip of the peninsula, where he is astonished by the changes he finds to the natural landscape. He is also struck by the warmth of the staff at the Suzu Horse Park, who are working to provide healing for the local people through their interactions with the horses.

programme.title: Document 72 Hours
programme.sub-title: The Convenience Store in a Midwinter Hokkaido Village
programme.desc: The Hokkaido village of Shosanbetsu is home to about 1,000 people and a single convenience store. Residents rely on this store as a source of fresh food and basic necessities, especially in midwinter. Among the customers were a woman who uses a sled to carry her shopping home; an octopus fisherman who shops there three times a day; and a hair stylist who knows everybody in Shosanbetsu. For three days as a blizzard buffeted the area, we spoke to the store's customers to get a glimpse at life in this village.

In Wajima, he meets people from the city's iconic Morning Market, who are working vigorously at a temporary location. And he meets with artisans who are keeping alive the traditions of Wajima-nuri lacquerware. He also visits a Buddhist temple, Soji-ji Soin, which suffered significant damage, and sees how the priests are restoring this essential pillar of the community. He then travels to Suzu City on the far tip of the peninsula, where he is astonished by the changes he finds to the natural landscape. He is also struck by the warmth of the staff at the Suzu Horse Park, who are working to provide healing for the local people through their interactions with the horses.

programme.title: Document 72 Hours
programme.sub-title: The Convenience Store in a Midwinter Hokkaido Village
programme.desc: The Hokkaido village of Shosanbetsu is home to about 1,000 people and a single convenience store. Residents rely on this store as a source of fresh food and basic necessities, especially in midwinter. Among the customers were a woman who uses a sled to carry her shopping home; an octopus fisherman who shops there three times a day; and a hair stylist who knows everybody in Shosanbetsu. For three days as a blizzard buffeted the area, we spoke to the store's customers to get a glimpse at life in this village.

programme.title: Science View
programme.sub-title: Biomimicry Changes the Future of Robotics
programme.desc: Robotic engineering continues to evolve swiftly, yet developing a robot that can detect and pursue odors has proved difficult for the science. Shunsuke SHIGAKI, an assistant professor at Osaka University, seeks to address the problem by analyzing the scent-detection abilities of silk moths. To understand how airflow or sight affect their perception of scents, he built a VR unit for insects in order to gather data. The algorithm created from it allowed him to program a robot with similar odor-detection capabilities. Now, he attempts to give it enough environmental adaptability to navigate obstacles, or operate outdoors. In this episode, we follow SHIGAKI's efforts to create a high-tech robot with abilities learned from actual organisms, so that it might eventually be put to use in search and rescue operations.

programme.sub-title: Hirosaki Neputa Matsuri: Hirosaki
programme.desc: Enormous floats called neputa paraded through the streets are the highlight of Hirosaki Neputa Matsuri in Hirosaki, Aomori Prefecture. The floats are decorated with vibrant images painted on washi paper. Some floats feature wireframe 3D figures. For most of the floats new art is produced every year, and preparations begin months in advance. This 300-year-old tradition began as a way to ward off drowsiness and keep people focused on farm work in the heat of summer.

programme.desc: The Shiretoko Peninsula, located in eastern Hokkaido Prefecture, juts into the Sea of Okhotsk. Its center is lined by 1,500-meter peaks. programme.title: A Culture Built with Wood
programme.sub-title: Hida
programme.desc: The Hida region in Gifu Prefecture has some of the country's most extensive broadleaf forests. Here, local artisans with sophisticated woodworking techniques are referred to as "Hida's Master Craftsmen," a title that has been respected for 1,300 years. Their skills are showcased in the floats of the Takayama Autumn Festival, ranked among the 3 most beautiful festivals in Japan. These floats are crafted using Japanese wood joinery techniques and do not use a single nail. Join us as we examine the craftsmanship that interlocks with the Hida region.

programme.sub-title: The Enduring Charm of Printed Timetables
programme.desc: Despite the rise of transfer apps, around 100,000 timetables are printed each month. Discover the charm of Japanese train timetables as we speak to the editors and the foreign residents who use them.

programme.title: NEWSROOM TOKYO
programme.desc: NEWSROOM TOKYO dives deeper into the day's news with insight and analysis, from the perspective of Japan and the rest of Asia. We put a spotlight on what you need to know to understand the issues.

programme.title: Direct Talk
programme.sub-title: Writing to Make a Dent in the World: Otani Akira / Author
programme.desc: In 2025, Otani Akira's book "The Night of Baba Yaga" won the UK's prestigious Dagger prize for crime fiction in translation - a first for a Japanese author. She talks about the inspiration behind her work.

programme.title: IMPACTS: Climates Change the World
programme.sub-title: On the Brink of Extinction?: Episode 5 Bee Decline and the Looming Food Crisis
programme.desc: Rising temperatures due to climate change have affected the behavior of bees, with fewer bees and shorter pollination periods, posing a threat to agriculture that could lead to a food crisis.

programme.title: Ukiyoe EDO-LIFE
programme.sub-title: The Series Summer Outfits by Kitagawa Utamaro
programme.desc: At dusk in summer, a woman is absorbed in reading a letter. This chic lady is actually an advertisement model for Mitsui Echigoya, one of the top kimono fabric stores in Edo.

programme.title: Medical Frontiers
programme.sub-title: Rectal Cancer: Advances in Anus-Preserving Surgery
programme.desc: Rectal cancer is increasing among younger people. Depending on the stage, a stoma may be needed. We report on efforts to preserve the anus using robotic-assisted surgery and artificial intelligence.

programme.title: OUR BLUE PLANET
programme.sub-title: The Path of Restoration to Save the Earth
programme.desc: Introducing the achievements of Blue Planet Prize winners Prof. Robert B. Jackson for carbon cycle research and greenhouse gas reduction, and Dr Jeremy Leggett for climate risk advocacy in finance.

programme.title: Time and Tide
programme.sub-title: YOKAI: Exploring Hidden Japanese Folklore - KIJIMUNA
programme.desc: KIJIMUNA of Okinawa, a red-haired child spirit in banyan trees, brings fortune to fishermen but punishes betrayal, embodying nature in local life.

programme.title: Magical Japanese
programme.sub-title: Grass
programme.desc: The Japanese people's coexistence with nature has led to many words and expressions related to kusa or "grass" taking root in the Japanese language.

programme.title: MATSURI: The Heartbeat of Japan
programme.sub-title: Gojinjo Taiko: Nafune-machi
programme.desc: Gojinjo Taiko is a wild, powerful performance by masked drummers. It originated 400 years ago in the small coastal community of Nafune-machi in Ishikawa Prefecture. The story goes that, faced with an imminent attack by a powerful warlord, villagers used improvised masks to disguise themselves as oni (demons), and scared away the approaching forces. Gojinjo Taiko is performed not only at the summer matsuri (festival) but at local hotels in everyday life, as a form of community revitalization.

programme.title: tiny desk concerts JAPAN
programme.sub-title: QUBIT
programme.desc: QUBIT, carrying on the spirit of Yellow Magic Orchestra, joins tiny desk concerts JAPAN! This 5-piece band has been celebrated for their innovative sound, topping the J-POP/Kayokyoku category in a major Japanese music magazine's 2023 rankings. They bring their signature electronic sound to NHK's Shibuya office, exciting the audience with a dynamic and organic experimental performance.

programme.title: BOSAI

programme.desc: Hokkaido Prefecture / Takeya Takayuki (Model maker) Fishing boats in the herring industry―which thrived here until the 1950s―featured swirling decorations that made a big impression on Takeya, a Hokkaido native.
